contextId.information: Fear is described as if it was something that attacked or overpowered Zechariah. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: fear fell on him

contextId.information: The heart is spoken of as if it is something that can be turned to go in a different direction. This refers to changing someone's attitude toward something. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: turn the hearts

contextId.information: Mary's baby is spoken of as if it is the fruit that a plant produces. AT: "the baby in your womb" or "the baby you will bear." (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the fruit of your womb

contextId.information: The horn of an animal is a symbol of its power to defend itself. The Messiah is spoken of as if he were a horn with the power to save Israel. AT: "someone with the power to save us" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: a horn of salvation for us

contextId.information: Darkness is here a metaphor for the absence of spiritual truth. Here, people who lack spiritual truth are spoken of as if they are sitting in darkness. AT: "people who do not know the truth" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: those who sit in darkness

contextId.information: The word "heavenly army" here could refer to a literal army of angels, or it could be a metaphor for an organized group of angels. AT: "a large group of angels from heaven" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: a great, heavenly army

contextId.information: A treasure is something that is very valuable or precious. Mary considered the things she was told about her son to be very precious. AT: "carefully remembering them" or "joyfully remembering them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: treasuring them in her heart

contextId.information: The words "downfall" and "rising up" express turning away from God and drawing closer to God. AT: "this child will cause many people in Israel to fall away from God or to rise closer to God" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: this child is appointed for the downfall and rising up of many people in Israel

contextId.information: This metaphor describes the deep sadness that Mary would feel. AT: "Your sadness will be painful as though a sword pierced your heart" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: a sword will pierce your own soul

contextId.information: The things that Mary heard are spoken of as if they were treasures that she carefully saved and valued. AT: "carefully remembered all these things" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: treasured all these things in her heart

contextId.information: "Get the road ready for the Lord." Doing this represents being prepared to hear the Lord's message when he comes. People do this by repenting of their sins. AT: "Prepare to hear the Lord's message when he comes" or "Repent and be ready for the Lord to come" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: Make ready the way of the Lord

contextId.information: When people prepare the road for an important person who is coming, they cut down the high places and fill in the low places so that the road will be level. This is part of the metaphor started in the previous verse. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Every valley will be filled ... every mountain and hill will be made low

contextId.information: In this metaphor, John compares the crowd to vipers, which were deadly or dangerous snakes and represent evil. AT: "You evil poisonous snakes!" or "People should stay away from you just like they avoid poisonous snakes!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: You offspring of vipers

contextId.information: In this metaphor, a person's behavior is compared to fruit. Just as a plant is expected to produce fruit that is appropriate for that kind of plant, a person who says that he has repented is expected to live righteously. AT: "produce the kind of fruit that shows that you have repented" or "do the good things that show that you have turned away from your sin" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: produce fruits that are worthy of repentance

contextId.information: This metaphor compares literal baptism that brings a person into contact with water to a spiritual baptism that brings them into contact with the Holy Spirit and with fire. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: He will baptize you with the Holy Spirit and with fire

contextId.information: John speaks of the Christ coming to judge as if he were a farmer who is ready to separate wheat grain from chaff. AT: "He is holding a winnowing fork because he is ready" or "He is ready to judge like a farmer who is ready to winnow grain" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: His winnowing fork is in his hand

contextId.information: The image of catching fish is being used as a metaphor for gathering people to follow Christ. AT: "you will fish for people" or "you will gather people for me" or "you will bring people to be my disciples" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: you will catch men

contextId.information: Jesus is comparing himself to the bridegroom, and the disciples to the wedding attendants. He did not explain the metaphor, so the translation should explain it only when necessary. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the bridegroom will be taken away from them

contextId.information: This metaphor contrasts the old teaching of the religious leaders against the new teaching of Jesus. The point is that people who are used to the old teaching are not willing to listen to the new things that Jesus is teaching. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: drinking old wine ... wants the new

contextId.information: The order of this sentence can be reversed. AT: "They will pour into your lap a generous amount that they have pressed down and shaken together until it is spilling over." Jesus used the metaphor of a grain merchant giving a generous amount. AT: "Like a grain merchant who presses down the grain and shakes it together and pours in so much grain that it spills over, they will give generously to you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: A generous amount ... your lap

contextId.information: This is a metaphor for a person's most important faults. A log could not literally go into a person's eye. Jesus is emphasizing that a person should pay attention to his own more important faults before he deals with another person's less important faults. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])
contextId.quote: the log that is in your own eye

contextId.information: Producing what is good is a metaphor for doing what is good. AT: "does what is good" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: produces what is good

contextId.information: In the parable this was a metaphor of a bird snatching away the seeds. Try to use words in your language that keep that image. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: takes away

contextId.information: This metaphor refers to the way weeds cut off light and nutrients from plants and keep them from growing. AT: "as weeds prevent good plants from growing, the cares, riches, and pleasures of this life keep these people from becoming mature" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: they are choked by ... pleasures of this life

contextId.information: "produce fruit by enduring patiently" or "produce fruit by continued effort." Fruit is a metaphor for good works. AT: "like healthy plants that produce good fruit, they produce good works by persevering" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: bear fruit with patient endurance

contextId.information: This metaphor expresses that the people who were coming to listen to Jesus were as important to him as his own family was. AT: "Those who hear the word of God and obey it are like a mother and brothers to me" or "Those who hear the word of God and obey it are as important to me as my mother and brothers" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: My mother and my brothers are those who hear the word of God and do it

contextId.information: "follow me." Coming after Jesus represents being one of his disciples. AT: "be my disciple" or "be one of my disciples" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: come after me

contextId.information: This metaphor could also be stated as a simile. AT: "it is like he is welcoming me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: welcomes me

contextId.information: Jesus does not mean literally that dead people will bury other dead people. Possible meanings of "the dead" are 1) it is a metaphor for those who will soon die, or 2) it is a metaphor for those who do not follow Jesus and are spiritually dead. The main point is that a disciple must not let anything delay him from following Jesus. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Leave the dead to bury their own dead

contextId.information: "There is a big crop, but not enough workers to bring it in." Jesus means there are many people ready to enter God's kingdom, but there are not enough disciples to go teach and help the people. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: The harvest is plentiful, but the laborers are few

contextId.information: "authority to step on snakes and crush scorpions." Possible meanings are 1) this refers to actual snakes and scorpions or 2) snakes and scorpions are a metaphor for evil spirits. The UDB translates this as referring to evil spirits: "I have given you the right to attack evil spirits" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: authority to tread on serpents, and scorpions

contextId.information: To knock at a door is to hit it a few times to let a person inside the house know you are standing outside. It can also be translated using the way people in your culture show that they have arrived, such as "call out" or "cough" or "clap." Here, it means a person should keep praying to God until he answers. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: knock

contextId.information: "crashes down and is destroyed." This image of the house collapsing refers to the destruction of a family when the members fight each other. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: falls

contextId.information: This speaks about Jesus defeating Satan and his demons as if Jesus was a stronger man who takes what belongs to a strong man. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: When a strong man ... man's possessions

contextId.information: This refers to the person in which he used to live. AT: "the person in whom I used to live!" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: my house from which I came

contextId.information: This part of the metaphor contrasts the careful way they clean the outside of the dishes with the way they ignore their own internal condition. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: but the inside of you is filled with greed and evil

contextId.information: "You put burdens on people that are heavy for them to carry." Jesus speaks about someone giving people many rules as if the person were giving them heavy things to carry. AT: "you burden people by giving them too many rules to follow" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: you burden men with burdens hard to carry

contextId.information: Jesus speaks about God's truth as if it were in a house that the teachers refuse to enter and will not let others have the key to enter either. This means the teachers do not truly know God, and they prevent others from knowing him as well. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: you have taken away the key of knowledge ... hinder those who are entering

contextId.information: This means they wanted Jesus to say something wrong so that they could accuse him. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: trying to trap him in his own words

contextId.information: Just as yeast spreads through a whole lump of bread dough, their hypocrisy was spreading through the whole community. AT: "Guard yourself against the hypocrisy of the Pharisees, which is like yeast" or "Be careful that you do not become hypocrites like the Pharisees. Their evil behavior influences everyone just as yeast affects a lump of dough" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Beware of the yeast of the Pharisees, which is hypocrisy

contextId.information: This is a metaphor because a cubit is a measure of length, rather than of time. The image is of a person's life stretched out as if it were a board, a rope, or some other physical object. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: add a cubit to his lifespan

contextId.information: "If God clothes the grass in the field like that" or "If God gives the grass in the field such beautiful clothing." AT: "If God makes the grass in the field beautiful like this" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: If God so clothes the grass in the field

contextId.information: Jesus was calling his disciples a flock. A flock is a group of sheep or goats that a shepherd cares for. As a shepherd cares for his sheep, God would care for Jesus' disciples. AT: "small group" or "dear group" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: little flock

contextId.information: "I came to throw fire on the earth" or "I came to set the earth on fire." Possible meanings are 1) Jesus has come to judge people or 2) Jesus has come to purify believers or 3) Jesus has come to cause division among people. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I came to cast fire upon the earth

contextId.information: Here "baptism" refers to what Jesus must suffer. Just as water covers a person during baptism, suffering will overwhelm Jesus. AT: "I must go through a baptism of terrible suffering" (UDB) or "I must be overwhelmed by suffering as a person being baptized is covered by water" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: But I have a baptism to be baptized with

contextId.information: Jesus compares people tying animals to the way Satan restricted the woman with this disease. AT: "whom Satan kept crippled by her illness" or "whom Satan bound with this disease" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: whom Satan bound

contextId.information: "Work hard to go through the narrow doorway." Jesus is speaking about the entrance to God's kingdom as if it were a small doorway to a house. Since Jesus is talking to a group, the "you" implied in this command is plural. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])
contextId.quote: Struggle to enter through the narrow door

contextId.information: This refers to the owner of the house with the narrow door in the previous verses. This is a metaphor for God as the ruler of the kingdom. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the owner of the house

contextId.information: It was common to speak of the joy in God's kingdom as a feast. AT: "and they will feast in the kingdom of God" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: and be seated at a table in the kingdom of God

contextId.information: Being first represents being important or honored. AT: "will be the most important ... will be the least important" or "God will honor them ... God will shame them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: will be first ... will be last

contextId.information: Jesus was calling Herod a fox. A fox is a small wild dog. Possible meanings are 1) Herod was not much of a threat at all 2) Herod was deceptive. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]]).
contextId.quote: that fox

contextId.information: This is a prophecy about something that would happen soon. It means that God has stopped protecting the people of Jerusalem, so enemies can attack them and drive them away. Possible meanings are 1) God will abandon them. AT: "God will abandon you" or 2) their city will be empty. AT: "your house will be abandoned" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: your house is abandoned

contextId.information: Jesus does not mean every Christian must be crucified. The Romans often made people carry their own crosses before they crucified them as a sign of their submission to Rome. This metaphor means they must submit to God and be willing to suffer in any way to be Jesus' disciples. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: carry his own cross

contextId.information: "Salt is useful." Jesus is teaching a lesson about those who want to be his disciple. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Salt is good

contextId.information: This metaphor speaks of the son being gone as if he was dead. AT: "it is as if my son was dead and became alive again" or "I felt like my son had died, but he is now alive" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: my son was dead, and now he is alive

contextId.information: The idea of days days coming represents something being soon. AT: "A time is coming when" or "Soon" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: The days are coming when

contextId.information: "receive life that does not end." The term "inherit" usually refers to the property that a man left to his children when  he dies. Therefore, this metaphor may mean he understood himself to be a child of God and desired for God to give him eternal life. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: inherit eternal life

contextId.information: "treasure in heaven" here refers to God's blessing. AT: "you will have God's blessings in heaven" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: you will have treasure in heaven

contextId.information: Jesus speaks of the temple as if it was a place where thieves come together. AT: "a place where thieves hide" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: a den of robbers

contextId.information: An empty hand is a metaphor for "nothing." AT: "sent him away without paying him" or "sent him away without the grapes" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: sent him away empty-handed

contextId.information: This second metaphor speaks of people who reject the Messiah as if they fall over a stone and are injured. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Every one who falls ... broken to pieces

contextId.information: "But whomever that stone falls on." This third metaphor speaks about the Messiah judging those who reject him as if he were a large stone that would crush them. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: But on whomever it falls

contextId.information: The Messiah's enemies are spoken of as if they were furniture on which he would rest his feet. This was an image of submission. AT: "until I make your enemies like a footstool for you" or "until I conquer your enemies for you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: until I make your enemies your footstool

contextId.information: "They also eat up widows' houses." The scribes are spoken of as if they were hungry animals that eat up everything the widows have. AT: "They also take away from widows all their possessions" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: They also devour widows' houses

contextId.information: The surface of the earth is spoken of as if it was the face of a person. That is, the outward part. AT: "on the surface of the whole earth" or "on the entire earth" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: on the face of the whole earth

contextId.information: Older people were respected in that culture. The leaders were usually older people and were called "elders." The youngest person would be the least likely to lead, and the least important. AT: "the least important" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the youngest

contextId.information: Jesus refers to the suffering that he is about to endure as if it were in a cup and that he was going to drink it. AT: "take away from me this cup of suffering" or "take away this suffering from me" or "rescue me from having to suffer like this" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: remove this cup from me

contextId.information: To appear before someone means to enter into their authority. AT: "to be judged by Pilate" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: before Pilate

contextId.information: The dry wood is a metaphor for something that will be useful only to burn. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: it is dry

contextId.information: The dawn here is a metaphor for the beginning of a day. For the Jews, the day began at sunset. AT: "it was soon going to be sunset, the start of the Sabbath" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the Sabbath was dawning

contextId.information: God's power will cover them in the same way that clothes cover a person. This can be stated in active form. AT: "you receive power" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: you are clothed with power
